original_solution_mapping.L1: John runs 100-4=<<100-4=96>>96 meters once he reaches his max speed
original_solution_mapping.L3: So he runs at a speed of 96/12=<<96/12=8>>8 m/s
original_solution_mapping.L4: So that means James's top speed is 8+2=<<8+2=10>>10 m/s
original_solution_mapping.L5: He has to run 100-10=<<100-10=90>>90 meters at his top speed
original_solution_mapping.L6: So he runs that at 90/10=<<90/10=9>>9 seconds
original_solution_mapping.L7: So he takes 9+2=<<9+2=11>>11 seconds to run 100 meters

original_function_code:
def solve():
    """Index: 5340.
    Returns: the total time it takes James to run 100 meters.
    """
    # L1
    total_race_distance = 100 # 100 meters
    john_initial_distance = 4 # 4 meters in the first second
    john_remaining_distance = total_race_distance - john_initial_distance

    # L2
    john_total_time = 13 # 13 seconds
    john_initial_time = 1 # first second
    john_remaining_time = john_total_time - john_initial_time

    # L3
    john_speed = john_remaining_distance / john_remaining_time

    # L4
    james_speed_increase = 2 # 2 m/s faster
    james_top_speed = john_speed + james_speed_increase

    # L5
    james_initial_distance = 10 # first 10 meters
    james_remaining_distance = total_race_distance - james_initial_distance

    # L6
    james_remaining_time = james_remaining_distance / james_top_speed

    # L7
    james_initial_time = 2 # first 10 meters in 2 seconds
    james_total_time = james_remaining_time + james_initial_time

    # FA
    answer = james_total_time
    return answer

logical_steps.solution_line_template: John runs {total_race_distance}-{john_initial_distance}=<<{total_race_distance}-{john_initial_distance}={john_remaining_distance}>>{john_remaining_distance} meters once he reaches his max speed
So he runs at a speed of {john_remaining_distance}/{john_remaining_time}=<<{john_remaining_distance}/{john_remaining_time}={john_speed}>>{john_speed} m/s
So that means James's top speed is {john_speed}+{james_speed_increase}=<<{john_speed}+{james_speed_increase}={james_top_speed}>>{james_top_speed} m/s
He has to run {total_race_distance}-{james_initial_distance}=<<{total_race_distance}-{james_initial_distance}={james_remaining_distance}>>{james_remaining_distance} meters at his top speed
So he runs that at {james_remaining_distance}/{james_top_speed}=<<{james_remaining_distance}/{james_top_speed}={james_remaining_time}>>{james_remaining_time} seconds
So he takes {james_remaining_time}+{james_initial_time}=<<{james_remaining_time}+{james_initial_time}={james_total_time}>>{james_total_time} seconds to run 100 meters
